proctext.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

question.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to his statement on Four Corners last night that:

question.para: I have always when getting a large donation off someone said to them that I'd make sure if they had a problem with government they'd be able to at least talk to the person with whom they had the problem.

Given the Minister's statement and the revelations in the Four Corners program, in the Minister's fund-raising activities what was his relationship with Terry Burke? Was the Minister aware that he received a 25 per cent commission on funds raised, amounting to $600,000 in one year? To the Minister's knowledge, were donors aware of the commission received by the Premier's brother, and in seeking funds did he also offer the inducement of access to Australian Labor Party Federal Ministers?

talk.start.para: —Order! I really do not think that the question is within the Minister's ministerial responsibility, but again I ask the Minister whether he wants to answer it or not.

—I would rather answer it, Mr President. As for my relationship with Terry Burke, I know Terry Burke. I have not seen him for a few years. I did not get the same commission either. I was not aware of the commission until the last couple of weeks; so the answer is no. I have no idea what he may have done or to whom he may have talked. It would not have been within my purview and, as I said, I did not know of any commission that he had received on any particular donation or on the whole.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Did the Australian Industrial Relations Commission hand down its decision today in the national wage case? Can the Minister advise the Senate what the elements of the decision are as it affects both wage earners and the process of economic reform? Can he also advise the Senate of the Government's reaction to the decision?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —The Full Bench of the national wage case handed down a decision in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission at 10 o'clock this morning in Melbourne. The decision was in response to a claim taken by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to seek, in short, the agreement by the Commission that accord mark 6 would be awarded as a wage package to Australian workers. Accord mark 6 consisted of a $12 wage increase from 16 June, a provision for a 3 per cent increase in superannuation entitlement by award employees commencing on a phased-in basis of one per cent a year from 1 July this year, and for guidelines to be handed down to guide company level negotiations in a managed decentralising of the centralised wage fixing system.

answer.para: The Commission decided in view of the submissions that it would award a 2.5 per cent wage increase to be applied for by unions to be added to their awards in exchange for a continuance by those unions of the structural efficiency process and award restructuring changes; for the superannuation claim to be recommended to go to a conference of the parties; and for any company level negotiation guidelines not to be imposed at this stage but inviting the parties to come back on 1 November next in order that that and other matters of wage fixation in Australia can be considered.

I am asked by Senator Foreman what the Government's reaction to this decision is. The Government's reaction is that we are disappointed that the national wage case bench did not endorse accord mark 6 in its entirety. We believe that the accord mark 6 package is sustainable and is appropriate in the current economic climate; that the flat $12 wage increase that I referred to as part of that package would have been better for lower income earners in Australia than a percentage amount of 2 1/2 per cent. Let me illustrate that: workers on average weekly earnings of $590 a week, under the 2 1/2 per cent increase, get $14.75. But low income earners typifying an average award earnings level of approximately $432 a week would get a $10.80 increase.

The $12 would have addressed the needs of lower income earners more fairly. We in the Government freely acknowledge that millions of Australian working people have shouldered the burden of restraint in this community, but we believe that it is wrong for the lower paid workers in this community, on a percentage increase, to shoulder a greater burden of that restraint.

The deferral of superannuation delays progress in the Government's retirement income strategy. We recognise that it is necessary to ensure that there is proper retirement provision to supplement age pensions. We are sorry that the Commission did not proceed with the claim in that respect. We will now consider our options on that issue.

talk.start.para: —Are you going to call a conference?

—I said we are considering our options on that issue. As far as the restructuring of the awards is concerned, we are pleased that the Commission has brought down a decision which will encourage further progress in that matter. But we are frustrated by the fact that, despite there being a tripartite consensus between employers, unions and the Government before the Commission, the Commission has at this stage decided not to hand down guidelines for company level negotiations.

answer.para: We would have thought that those guidelines would be appropriate in the circumstances but we will now build on the consensus that exists between employers, unions and the Government around that issue to redress the matter before the Commission in November. I point out, however, that there is extensive flexibility within the existing principles, and the most obvious flexibility is for certified agreements now to be taken out where, at a company level, negotiations between employers and unions come to an appropriate outcome for that enterprise. That is clearly the way that the Commission is now signalling they should go.

On the last point, enterprise or company level negotiations, there is no interchangeability of terms as far as the Government is concerned in the context of the way in which the Opposition uses this term. Mr Howard frequently uses this term; he is to the right of Greiner on this matter. At least the Greiner Government recognises the Professor Niland thesis, that there should be in Australia what amounts to collective bargaining and bargaining based on the enterprise. In that thesis the right to strike is an element of the package.

Mr Howard does not recognise that. He wants to take Australia down the New Zealand road-a road in which there is no Commission, no umpire, and therefore no assurance of fair play. He wants to take Australia down the New Zealand road, which bypasses the union's role in representing workers in a workplace negotiation, and have individuals negotiate at enterprise level their individual work contracts with the big company, as if one person in a negotiation with a major company represents fair play.

I want to differentiate between the terms. We are talking about enterprise negotiation in a vastly different and more managed way with the social partners, the employers and the unions, not in the extremist view that the Opposition is presenting.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Minister's extraordinary admission on last night's Four Corners program that large donors can buy a hotline to Australian Labor Party Ministers. Does it follow that the many thousands of welfare recipients with many problems but no cash simply go to the back of the queue? If not, exactly what type of preferential access is up for sale? Are these sordid and amoral priorities official Government policy or are they simply a graphic confirmation of Lord Acton's dictum that `power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely'?

—Over the course of the past couple of weeks I have sat down with groups of homeless kids in Sydney and Melbourne-with the Brotherhood of St Laurence in Melbourne and with a number of refuge workers in Sydney. I cannot recall how much money they gave us, but I suspect it was nothing because they had nothing. Nevertheless, I went out to visit them. Over the course of the past couple of months I have also been all over Australia, including to the country areas of New South Wales, visiting the homes of sole parents who cannot afford shoes for their children. I cannot say that I recall their giving us any money either because they had none. Therefore, the idea that access is given only to those who are Party donors is nonsense. I simply made the statement that when I was raising money-and that does not go for anyone else in the Labor Party-I would guarantee people access. Fortunately, in the case of Laurie Connell he never asked for it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister please explain who does not get access under that sort of arrangement? If a welfare recipient who pays nothing gets access and if someone who pays $250,000 gets access, who does not get access? Is Laurie entitled to his money back?

—The reality is this: those who have given large donations and who thought they were getting special privileges, do not get them. All those businesses which pay large sums of money-not just to political parties but to lobbyists and all sorts of people-do not get anything special either. The truth is that Ministers in this Government have made themselves available to a whole range of Australians and do so every day. It makes no difference whether it is those who give lots or those who give nothing.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a delegation of children from the Soviet Union who were victims of the Chernobyl accident. Whilst it is not normal to welcome such a delegation, I am sure that all honourable senators would join me in wishing them well on their visit to Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Australian Government know of a list of companies and individuals declared on 1 April by the United States (US) Treasury to be agents and front companies in Iraq's arms procurement and financial network, as referred to in an article in the Australian on Monday this week by Frank Devine? What can the Minister tell us about those companies, including the countries they operate in, and can he table the list of names? Are any such companies or individuals known to be operating in Australia?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —Yes, we do know of the list of 52 companies and 37 individuals that was publicly released by US Treasury Deputy Secretary Robson on 1 April. The people and companies in question were determined by the US authorities to be agents and front companies in Iraq's arms procurement and financial network. I have a copy of the list in question here and I am prepared to table it because it is a public document.

answer.para: According to the list, 32 of the companies have addresses in the United Kingdom. The remaining companies have addresses in a variety of countries including: Iraq, India, Jordan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Brazil, the United States, Italy, Sri Lanka, Germany, United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Bahrain and the Yemen Arab Republic. Secretary Robson said that this network of front companies and agents had strengthened Saddam Hussein's military capability and may have facilitated transfers of funds out of Iraq. US entities are prohibited by regulation from engaging in unlicensed transactions with companies and individuals determined to be owned or controlled by the Government of Iraq, or acting, or purporting to act directly or indirectly on its behalf.

The result of the US Treasury action has been to deny the 89 businesses and individuals listed an opportunity to have business relations and access to financial resources within US jurisdiction. We have been in contact with United States officials and are examining whether any of these companies or individuals has any connection to Australia. However, to our knowledge at this stage, none of those named in the published list does have such an Australian connection. I table the document.

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen reports that Australia will resume aid to Burma, even though the military regime there still has a terrible human rights record and is still holding the leader of the National League for Democracy (NLD), Ms Aung San Suu Kyi, under house arrest? Are these reports true?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —There is no truth to any report that Australia is about to resume aid to Burma. As I said in this place in July last year, the Australian Government's policy is not to review the suspension of our aid program to Burma until a transfer of power to a democratically elected government has taken place.

answer.para: Australia has been very firm in its calls for a transition to a democratic form of government in Burma and in its calls for the results of the May 1990 elections to be respected, in accordance with the wishes of the majority of the people in Burma.

talk.start.para: —Why did the Australian ambassador suggest you were reviewing it?
—He may have suggested that, at least as reported, but there was no foundation for any such suggestion. I have stated that clearly and I repeat it for Senator Hill's benefit.

answer.para: The Government will continue to do all it can through bilateral and multilateral representations to achieve a transfer of power to a democratic government in Burma. The military regime has responded to last year's election victory by the National League for Democracy with what can only be described as a series of repressive and intimidatory measures violating fundamental human rights. The leader of the National League for Democracy, Ms Aung San Suu Kyi, remains, as Senator Bourne said, under house arrest, almost two years after she was first detained. By the regime's own admission, over 35 elected members of the NLD or affiliated parties, as well as others political activists, remain under detention and may yet be put on trial. The Australian Government has condemned these abuses and has taken every opportunity, including direct representations, to encourage the military regime to observe internationally accepted standards of human rights, to release all political prisoners and to accede to the popular desire for democracy.

I am able to say a little further that press reports about a resumption of Australian aid were based on an interview with the Australian Ambassador to Burma. These reports were accurate in so far as they reported his assessment that a transfer of power to a democratic government in Burma appears to be a long way off and his view that Australia will have to accept these political realities. However, reports that the Ambassador spoke of any policy shift or suggested that any resumption of aid could be expected in the short term are quite inaccurate. I repeat that the Government's policy remains as I have stated it and the Ambassador is fully aware of that.

talk.start.para: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade comment on whether the decision by the European Community (EC) to lift bans on imports of gold coins, iron and steel from South Africa will have any impact on Australia's position regarding sanctions and South Africa?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The EC first foreshadowed the removal of sanctions on South African iron, steel and gold coins-Kruger rands as they are called-at the EC heads of government meeting in Rome in December. The EC tied the lifting of these sanctions to the tabling of legislation to repeal the group areas and land Acts. With that legislation now tabled, the EC announcement yesterday comes as no surprise. From an Australian and Commonwealth perspective, its timing remains unhelpful and unfortunate. In our view, it is too soon to be lifting trade sanctions. We regard the maintenance of pressure on South Africa as being crucial at this stage when promises must still be translated into actions.

answer.para: The EC still has in place a range of sanctions that it did impose in 1985, including the arms embargo, a ban on oil exports to South Africa and the prohibition of new collaboration in the nuclear sector. We certainly hope that there will not be any move by the EC to lift those sanctions at present. The Australian and Commonwealth position on sanctions was made very clear at the London meeting of the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa in February. At that meeting the Commonwealth agreed to a phased approach to the lifting of sanctions as the South African Government met its various commitments to dismantle apartheid.

On that basis, we can expect in the first instance the lifting of the so-called `people oriented' sanctions-which include restrictions on cultural, academic and scientific contacts; visas; the promotion of tourism and air links-once the South African Government has met that series of specific initial conditions, namely, the release of remaining political prisoners; the removal of obstacles preventing the return of exiles; the review and repeal of repressive security legislation; and the actual repeal of the three important pillar pieces of legislation, the group areas, land and population registration Acts. Other sanctions will be lifted in accordance with the Commonwealth agreement once further major steps are taken towards constitutional reform.

Finally, the United States of America is committed to leaving sanctions in place until the South African Government complies with the conditions established under the comprehensive anti-apartheid Act. It seems wholly unlikely that those conditions will be met, even on a fairly optimistic view, before the end of June.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to evidence to the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters-I think by Senator Beahan-that he was a signatory to a secret campaign fund known as the union fighting fund, together with Terry Burke. I ask: what was the purpose of this fund? How much money passed through the fund? Has the Government subsequently made grants to unions which provided funds through this secret channel?
—Order! Again, I make the point that I do not think that this is a matter within ministerial responsibility. If the Minister wants to answer it, he can, or he need not.
—Mr President, the question is based on a false premise. Since that premise is false it does not seem to me appropriate to answer the rest of the question which is constructed on a falsity.
—Mr President, I would seek to press the question but I am concerned about your ruling. I wonder if I might have the opportunity to address you.
—I have not ruled the question out of order, Senator Hill.

—If you have not ruled the question out of order, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister again: what was the purpose of the fund; how much money passed through the fund; and the most important part of the question, which must be a matter going to public affairs, is, has the Government subsequently made grants to unions which provided contributions to this fund?

—I just ask Senator Hill, if he is going to ask me this question which is a question that came before a royal commission, that he concentrate on accuracy lest he use the forum of Parliament and the privileges that attend this forum to abuse justice. The question that he has asked me through you, Mr President, is a false question. I do not feel any responsibility to answer questions which are based on a false premise.

question.speaker: Vallentine Sen J.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware of a letter addressed to him by Friends of the Earth which challenges a number of statements in his own letter to the Australian Labor Party's uranium advisory committee? Does the Minister still stand by his statements? Specifically, does Mr Kerin stand by the following statement in his letter:

question.para: Japan and South Korea have nuclear development programmes that call for an additional 40 nuclear power stations in 20 years and 55 reactors in 40 years respectively.

Is the Minister aware that, according to a recent report in the industry publication Nuclear News, Japan has a total of only 15 additional reactors on firm order or under construction, and South Korea only an additional three reactors? Can the Minister explain this discrepancy? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that, in Japan, only two reactors are currently scheduled to come on line after 1995? All other reactors are expected on line before 1995. Therefore, can the Minister explain his Department's prediction of a rapid expansion in Japan after 1995?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —Apparently, Mr Kerin had some notice of this question because he has supplied me with an answer. I am advised that the figures quoted by Mr Kerin clearly relate to the announced plans by Japan and Korea for longer term development, and the letter states that directly.

answer.para: Such plans should not be confused with shorter term predictions based on reactors currently being built or under construction. Mr Kerin acknowledged in his letter that these estimates might prove optimistic but pointed out that there can be no doubting that Japan's and Korea's economic growth are inextricably linked to ambitious nuclear-powered developments.

Irrespective of the rate of growth of the nuclear industry in Japan or Korea or worldwide, many of Australia's major trading partners continue to rely on Australia for supply of vital energy resources. For many, these resources include uranium. Their dependence on nuclear power for electricity generation will continue and increase; that can be documented. Australia has a well-deserved reputation as a reliable supplier of energy resources to our trading partners. This is a more crucial consideration for the Government.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Government support moves by the Opposition to try to find uranium buyers amongst countries which are not signatories to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, such as Taiwan? Is that also conceded by the Government to be a growth area for the uranium industry in Australia?

—The Australian Government's policy on the supply of uranium is quite clearly linked to countries meeting the requirements on safeguards. Those countries meet that requirement by signing the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, or they come to accept the terms of that Treaty applying to them in their particular country.

—My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It follows his non-answer to my last question. In what respect was the premise of my question false? Is he saying that he was not a signatory to this secret campaign fund, or is he saying that the evidence that Senator Beahan gave to the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters was false?

—I have no obligation to tell Senator Hill where he is wrong and where he is right. Senator Hill rises in this place to ask me a question which is false. The elements of that question which are false can be uncovered by going to the record and examining it. I am not going to give in or yield to an attempt by Senator Hill to smear me or trade unions by answering a false question. If he wants to ask an accurate question, I will answer it.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of the new code of industry practice on the portrayal of violence on television? Is he satisfied that it provides sufficient safeguards to ensure that the television industry takes public concerns about the impact of the broadcast of violent material into account in its programming decisions?

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided me with the following information. In 1988, the Government asked the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) to conduct a major inquiry into the portrayal, depiction and reporting of violence on television. This initiative arose out of concern expressed during the Premiers Conference on gun control in December 1987, which was, in turn, in response to events such as the Queen Street and Hoddle Street massacres. The ensuing report recommended an approach of supervised self-regulation as the best response to the acknowledged community concern about violence on television. In the judgment of the Tribunal, the industry has now acknowledged the public concern and has committed itself to ways of rectifying the situation. The Government fully supports the recommendation made in the Tribunal's report, but it has acted to ensure that safeguards can be put into place if necessary.

answer.para: In the past few months, the ABT has worked closely with the television industry to develop a comprehensive code on violence to guide program makers and schedulers. Although this code is an industry code, it is subject to acceptance by the ABT and the Tribunal will regularly measure the progress of its implementation through the normal commercial television licence renewal process. The interests of the public will be further safeguarded through an ABT review of the effectiveness of this code after six months of operation. The code outlines what material might cause serious distress to viewers, provides for warnings of material which may cause offence, and gives guidelines as to where violent and distressing material should or should not be used.

The report stresses that individuals in the community must also accept a responsibility to regulate their own, and their children's, viewing. The Government is pleased to note that the television industry has agreed to undertake a public awareness campaign so that as many people as possible know about the new code and can use it to plan their own viewing. The campaign should also inform more members of the public on how to take timely action to complain of any suspected breaches of the code.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. In view of the Minister's remarks that the trade unions are treated in the same way as any other donors to political parties, I ask him: with the purchase of part of John Curtin House in Canberra by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, would rent payable by the Australian Labor Party be tax deductible for the Labor Party and tax free in the hands of the ACTU?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —I think that matter is very much one for the Commissioner of Taxation. The point I made yesterday and the point that I go back to is that there are two aspects to this question. The trade unions and employer associations are treated equally under the law. In respect of the Government's proposal to pursue disclosure legislation, what is in issue is not where the money comes from, how it is earned or whether it is from overseas or whatever; the basic issue is disclosure, not only of donations but also of income and expenditure.

answer.para: I am not the Tax Commissioner. I cannot make a ruling as to tax provisions. All I will say is that both trade union and employer associations are equally exempt from income tax by specific provisions of the law.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of comments by Mr Peter Costello, the Opposition spokesman on corporate law reform and consumer affairs, on the Matt Abraham program this morning on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio in which he made the fanciful claim that it was the Federal coalition which was responsible for the move from the cooperative scheme of corporate regulation involving State and Federal schemes to the uniform national scheme currently in place? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the facts leading to the introduction of the current national scheme?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I have seen a transcript of the interview-although I did not listen to it-between Mr Costello, the Opposition spokesman on business and consumer affairs, and Matt Abraham this morning on ABC radio. I must say that it amounts to a complete rewriting of the history of the regulation of companies and securities in the Commonwealth of Australia. Mr Costello says:

answer.para: . . . the absolute failure of corporate regulation under the Hawke Government is transparent but over the last seven or eight years they showed absolutely no interest whatsoever in enforcing the current laws and ensuring that they did something to protect shareholders and creditors.

The fact is that that is completely and utterly inconsistent with the historical record. I am only sorry that the Russian school children have departed the gallery because they would see in Mr Peter Costello's comments the same rewriting of history as occurred in Russia under the old regime before glasnost and perestroika.

The fact is that it was the coalition which introduced the inadequate arrangements under the National Companies and Securities Commission which led to a situation where there was no clear line of political responsibility from that Commission to any one parliament or to any one Minister responsible to a parliament. It took this Government to introduce legislation to make sure that in relation to companies and securities regulation there was one parliament, namely, this Parliament, which created the laws and one Minister, namely the Federal Attorney-General, who was responsible for the correct, proper, adequate and forceful enforcement of that legislation.

In fact, it took four or five years of tortuous debate in this chamber after the report handed down by a committee under the chairmanship of Senator Nick Bolkus, and overcoming a lot of obstruction in this place, before that framework could be put into place. Mr Costello also said of the Western Australian situation:
It was the Federal Coalition that persuaded them-
that is, the upper House in Western Australia-
to go along with a national scheme.

That is completely and utterly absurd. In fact, the coalition parties in the upper House in Western Australia rejected what late overtures were made to it by Dr Hewson. It was not until the business community in Western Australia realised the absurd situation that it was being led into by the upper House in Western Australia that the coalition in that chamber collapsed.

Indeed, it was only when it was revealed, for example, that sharebrokers in Western Australia would have to withdraw from that State and relocate in South Australia that the situation became so patently intolerable as far as the business community in Western Australia was concerned. In Western Australia there was a secessionist mentality, a la 1930, whereby the coalition forces in the upper House in Western Australia wanted effectively to withdraw from the national marketplace. That had to be overcome by the sheer force of our persuasion and that of the business community in Western Australia between last Christmas and the new year.

Finally, Mr Costello said that what one needed was a more vigilant Australian Securities Commission. That is precisely what this Government has provided by giving very adequate funding to enable 16 major investigations to be undertaken by Mr Hartnell and the Australian Securities Commission. The Australian Securities Commission was opposed right up to the last minute even by the Federal coalition and certainly by the coalition forces in Western Australia. It is precisely this Government that has provided a mechanism, under Mr Hartnell and the Australian Securities Commission, to forcefully ensure that the will of the Parliament in relation to companies and securities regulation is fulfilled.

I believe that everything Mr Costello has said about the record of the Federal Government in this respect is utterly at odds with the historical record, and I am pleased that Senator Beahan, as the Chairman of the new Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, has a very real interest in these matters, and has brought it to the attention of the chamber.

question.speaker: Olsen Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. In Senator Powell's statement yesterday on widening the political advertising ban legislation to include regulation of editorial content of the print media, it was said:

question.para: . . . if somebody is mentioned then nothing should be published or broadcast until that person is right there with their reply . . .

Given that statement and given that the Government has been negotiating for six months with the Australian Democrats, does the Government now support the Democrats' call to widen its political advertising legislation to include regulating the editorial processes of the print and electronic media?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —At the outset, let me say that I have not seen the specifics of Senator Powell's statement. I have seen some reports of it, but the reports differ. The Government's motivation in presenting its package of proposals is two-fold: firstly, to ensure a transparent process; and, secondly, to reduce the cost of campaigning. We believe-and we have some support in this-that the total problem cannot be addressed solely by disclosure legislation. That is one issue that this Senate and the Democrats have to grapple with.

answer.para: When we look at the fact that over the last three election campaigns, for instance, electronic advertising costs have increased three-fold, we see that there is an enormous problem. That cannot be addressed purely by disclosure legislation; nor can it be addressed by those sorts of provisions that Senator Powell has reportedly been talking about. There are two motivations, and we believe that this Parliament has a responsibility to address them as one total package because disclosure legislation is not enough.

Contrary to the mumblings of the Opposition, we are supported here even by Mr Howard. In an article at the weekend, Mr Howard made the point that the United States has had elaborate disclosure laws for years. These did not stop a former Vice-President, Spiro Agnew, from receiving corrupt payments while occupying the second highest political position in that country. We have a position which goes both to the costs of campaigning as well as to the need to disclose donations and the income and expenditure of political parties and third party organisations.

Senator Powell's points with respect to fairness in broadcasting and truth in advertising do not go to those particular issues and do not address the enormous costs of campaigning. She has put those positions. I have not seen the details of them, but if the proposal is for an instant right of reply, as Senator Olsen has depicted and as I have read in the press, obviously it is not a goer. But if Senator Powell is talking about something else, I am sure I will get it directly from her and not through newspapers.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When does the Government intend to introduce its `package of proposals' and specifically which Act or Acts will be amended?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —As we have already announced, the Government's package of proposals go to amending both the Electoral Act as well as the Broadcasting Act. They are the substantial pieces of legislation that will be addressed. Secondly, as we have also announced, it is our intention to introduce that package, that legislation, to this Parliament as soon as is technically possible. We have to await the drafting of that legislation.

answer.para: When we made the decision to introduce legislation, I made it clear that it was our intention to do so before the Senate got up in June or July. It was also our intention to try to have that legislation passed by the Senate by that time. So there is no reluctance on the part of this Government to proceed with this. We recognise that we have to address the issues. I must say, Senator Olsen, that we have recognised issues in this area for quite some time. We have recognised the need to alleviate the cost of campaigning. We have also recognised the need for disclosure legislation.

Let me also say that at every turn over the last seven years we have met with strident opposition from the other side. Let me make a prediction about the Opposition's new conversion to disclosure legislation. There are so many holes in Dr Hewson's statement on disclosure, there are so many contradictions with that of Mr Goldsworthy, there are so many qualifications that the Opposition will not support it in the end, as it has resisted it in the past. The Opposition will throw in irrelevant issues. But to us, the basic issue of disclosure legislation-the one that we are proposing-is that such legislation will go as far as is constitutionally possible. It will be based on the principle of equity and the principle of transparency. What we are concerned about is to obtain legislation in this Parliament as soon as possible to provide full disclosure.

In terms of when-let me answer that once more. Let me put this on the table in closing: when this legislation gets through the Parliament depends very much on what sort of opposition we will get from the Opposition. The Opposition has had a long history of opposing this sort of legislation in the past. If it is frustrated in its passage through the Parliament, it will only be because of the Opposition side.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of attempts to avoid the gold tax by the industry stockpiling large amounts of gold ore removed from the ground before 1 January 1991? Can the Minister confirm whether the value of the gold refined from these stockpiles will be subject to income tax? If the answer is yes to that question, is it correct that that revenue will be reduced by the value of the stockpiles as valued at 1 January 1991? Finally, will the Government request the Commissioner of Taxation to examine the valuation of these stockpiles to ensure that there is no manipulation of the value of the stocks which would reduce the tax otherwise payable?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —It is inevitable in circumstances when there is any change in government charges of one kind or another that companies operating in the field on which new charges will be imposed or old charges removed will probably seek to take advantage of that situation. It happens every time there is a tariff cut, every time there is a Budget or every time there are new proposals in respect of government charges on companies.

answer.para: In so far as the goldmining industry is concerned, from 1 January 1991 the goldmining industry became subject to income tax on the same basis as other industries. Transition arrangements are based on standard taxation principles. In particular, allowance is made for any stocks of ore and other partly or fully processed material that may be on hand as at 1 January 1991.

The effect of these arrangements is that profit accrued up to 1 January 1991 from business activity in the gold industry conducted prior to 1 January 1991, which may be reflected in the value of stocks at that time, will be free of tax whereas profit arising from activity conducted after 1 January 1991 will be subject to income tax in the normal way.

In so far as the last part of the question involves a request for valuations of stockpiles and so on by the Taxation Commissioner, I am sure that is a matter which the Commissioner will have in hand as normal practice. But in case that is not so, I will have that passed on.

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Could the Minister advise the Senate how much revenue was lost due to the delayed implementation of the gold tax, taking into account that the industry had two years notice?
—I do not have that figure. I do not know whether it would be possible to estimate, but I will make some further inquiries about it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister aware of reports in the Brisbane media today that sailors from HMAS Sydney and Brisbane returning from duty in the Gulf have been told that there will not be a welcome home march in Brisbane on Friday and of the numerous representations from their families and friends? Is he also aware that those reports indicate that the march has been cancelled so as to allow the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Ray and other Federal politicians to spend time on those ships? Can the Minister look into this matter and consider an alternative arrangement so that the sailors can be given the proper recognition they deserve with a march in the streets of Brisbane when they arrive home and not at some future date well after the event?

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —I have no intention of organising a march in Brisbane when the ships come back in. My decision is based on discussions with the various sailors on those ships. When those ships berth, the sailors do not want to waste another eight hours marching through Brisbane or anywhere else; they want to reunite with family and friends, have a quiet ale in some cases, et cetera.

answer.para: Senator Bjelke-Petersen has also raised the question of inopportune timing. My original timing for these sorts of visits is to have the VIPs go on board the ships before they land, so that when the ships pull in the sailors do not have politicians getting in the road when they have their family reunions.

In my absence last week, the timing of the visits was changed. People did not think through the consequences of that. I subsequently looked at it on my return to Australia and reverted to the original timetable. This afternoon I am involved in the process of contacting everyone, including a couple of colleagues here, to try to re-establish the original timetable. That will mean that the various VIPs will meet the ships around 8.30 a.m.; the ships will then proceed up the Brisbane River, as did all the previous ships when they visited other ports, and things will run according to that plan.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen raised two points. One was about the timing. That has now been fixed, or was in the process of being fixed this afternoon. In relation to a march, I think it gives more joy to those who are greeting the march, than the marchers. However, we have said that once all servicemen have returned from the Gulf-and I remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen that the divers, the people from Western Australia and some personnel from the logistics support element are still in the Middle East-it would then be appropriate to have one march. That is being planned for August. It has been planned for Sydney, not necessarily out of any preference for Sydney, but because that is where the majority of the servicemen live.

I think that is the most appropriate time to have a march. Again, I guess it is a matter of choice. But I think that if a sailor who has been at sea for that amount of time lobs in at 11 o'clock, he does not really want to be told that he is going on a three or four-hour march so that everyone can wave flags. It is a time for families.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: Has the Minister seen reports of interest having been expressed by the Soviet Union in joining the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) conference prior to Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to Japan? What is the Government's response to this interest and under what criteria would Soviet involvement in APEC be welcomed?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I have seen those reports and they reflect a number of earlier indications of interest that have been given by the Soviet authorities to the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation process and the possibility of their eventually becoming participants in it. The response to date by the APEC participants, including Australia, has been to say that the crucial criterion for membership is the degree of economic linkage between the country in question and the other 12 existing participants in the APEC group. While the Soviet far east in particular manifestly has the potential to become a flourishing regional economy in its own right with a substantial set of linkages with Japan, China and the other countries in the region, those linkages simply do not exist at the moment. Of course, in the present economic circumstances confronting the Soviet Union there is rather less likelihood that they will be rapidly developed than might previously have been the case. I would not expect any rapid move towards the perception that that criterion will be satisfied. Some have suggested that it should also be regarded as a relevant consideration whether the country in question has a market economy. I think that is regarded by most of the APEC participants as a less relevant criterion than the sheer fact of existing or impending linkage of the kind that I have described.

answer.para: What is important about the APEC process is that it embrace as many as humanly possible of all the significant economies in the region. It is only with that degree of participation that the objectives of APEC in terms of regional and worldwide trade liberalisation, sectoral cooperation, data exchange and so on can be fully realised. With that in mind, the first priority of the APEC countries at the moment is to try to accomplish the participation in the process of the three big economies in the region which manifestly have such links at the moment, and they are the People's Republic of China, Taiwan and Hong Kong. As I said in answer to a question earlier this week, that process is well and truly in train. We hope very much that that will be able to be achieved by the Seoul meeting in October. I think that it will be a rather longer process achieving consensus about the appropriateness of Soviet participation, but it is certainly not something that any of us would wish to rule out in principle.

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister for Industrial Relations initiated a review of the 1988 Commonwealth employees' compensation scheme? If so, what are the terms of reference of the review? Who has been consulted about the operation of the scheme in the past two years and when will the review report?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —I have initiated a review of Comcare, which is referred to as the Commonwealth superannuation and rehabilitation scheme. I do not have the terms of reference available, but I will make them available to Senator Reid. Those terms of reference would spring from a desire by any government to ensure that the scheme operated efficiently, delivered its benefits to the best level to its members and ensured that rehabilitation was given primacy in the concerns of Commonwealth employees who have suffered accidents.

answer.para: I regard Comcare's performance as a provider of compensation and rehabilitation services to members of the Australian Public Service as good. It has improved its reputation by taking steps to ensure that, where injured workers are required to be off work, they are got back into the working environment as soon as possible, even if that means redesigning their jobs, so that they are not cut off from the normal society that they enjoy at work and not left to suffer loss of self-esteem at home while they are recovering from serious injuries. That has meant that the cost of premiums has fallen significantly to the recipient departments and agencies to which Comcare provides its service. The terms of reference reflect an inquiry to see whether that can be improved upon. I do not have it in my mind exactly when the inquiry is to report, but I have it in mind that it is to report fairly soon. I will provide that information to Senator Reid.

talk.start.para: —Has the attention of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs been drawn to the allegation made by David Barnett in the Bulletin of 16 April that, during the Gulf crisis, `Hawke, with his own life in danger, found the security services were less capable than they ever had been. They were lacking in clear directions and were less senior'. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether this allegation has any foundation?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I am happy to assure Senator Sherry, and indeed the chamber and the nation, that the allegation is without foundation. The Prime Minister and I were very happy with the performance of the security and counter-terrorist forces during the course of the conflict relating to the safety and welfare of Australians both at home and abroad.

answer.para: We would all recognise that the great strength and maturity of the Australian community, as a multicultural community, came through during the course of that crisis. The lack of many incidents of harassment or, indeed, of real violence is a tribute to that strength and maturity of our Australian community. The fact that there were no grave incidents of violence is due to that underlying maturity.

However, at the same time, the professionalism of those Federal, State and Territory government agencies, which were involved in security intelligence and counter-terrorism matters, preventative measures and so on, was very evident to me-and I had very close contact with them during the course of the conflict. The Prime Minister wrote to me on 15 March-well before the article written by David Barnett-to say, amongst other things:

The challenges that we have faced to this point have required a sustained and concerted effort involving a great many Commonwealth and State officials. I have every confidence that their efforts will continue to be directed towards ensuring Australia remains free from the scourge of international terrorism.
Now seems a particularly appropriate time to thank all concerned for their continuing vigilance during a difficult time.
The Prime Minister's comments in that regard were very well founded. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator the Hon Michael Tate
Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
My dear Minister

You will be aware that I have taken the opportunity to visit a number of the Government's agencies which have a central role in advising the Government during the hostilities in the Persian Gulf. That visit enabled me to thank the staff personally and to record the Government's deep appreciation for the work being done.

I am equally conscious that there are a great many more who have worked tirelessly, with the dedication and professionalism that we as a Government have become accustomed to, in providing advice to the Government and in ensuring the safety and welfare of Australians, both at home and abroad.

The challenges that we have faced to this point have required a sustained and concerted effort involving a great many Commonwealth and State officials. I have every confidence that their efforts will continue to be directed towards ensuring Australia remains free from the scourge of international terrorism.
Now seems a particularly appropriate time to thank all concerned for their continuing vigilance during a difficult time.
I should be grateful if you would pass on to those responsible my sincere personal thanks, together with those of the Government, for their efforts.
Yours sincerely
BOB HAWKE
R.J.L. Hawke

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that the dedication and the professionalism of many people in various agencies who worked very long hours during that conflict have been demonstrated and vindicated. I am sure that the safety of Australians both here and overseas was assured by their vigilance and by the actions and activities that they undertook.

—The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce would be well aware that Tasmania, per capita of the population, is a significant exporter. Can the Minister confirm that his Department is currently considering the recommendations of the McKinsey review into the operations and administrative structure of Austrade; that, under the recommendations of the review, Austrade operational staff numbers should be increased in regional areas; and that in direct contradiction of the findings of the report the Tasmanian and other regional offices may in fact be closed and their operations transferred to larger metropolitan centres? Can the Minister give an unequivocal assurance that the Tasmanian regional office of Austrade will not be closed or have its present minimal staff of four cut even further?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —Senator Tate, as another diligent senator from Tasmania, has already approached me about this issue. He drew to my attention the fact that some very good work had been done by the Austrade office in Tasmania, quite apart from its normal functions in expanding its activities a little.

answer.para: The question has four parts: yes, there is a review into the operations of Austrade. I do not know what Senator Watson means by operational staff numbers being increased in regional areas. Certainly the burden of the report is that operational staff numbers should be increased in this region of the world and in various countries of the Asia-Pacific region as distinct from North America and Europe where more common languages and more common business cultures apply.

The closing of regional offices is a matter which has to be worked through and negotiated with the States in part and that process is in train at the present time. I cannot give an unequivocal guarantee about the Tasmanian office. But when that matter comes to me on the basis of a recommendation from Austrade or discussions with Austrade, I will bear in mind the representations which have been made to me by Senator Tate and Senator Watson.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Before the Minister is forced to resign on 6 May on his own undertaking, will the Minister explain why the Prime Minister claimed in the 12 March statement that two enterprise agreements had been achieved, when he knew full well that the agreement between the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia (WWF) and Conaust Ltd had not been finalised because of a set of union claims, including a wage claim which, if not acceded to, would cancel not only the Conaust agreement but also other enterprise agreements? What is the percentage wage increase being demanded by the unions? To what extent would the wage increase demanded offset the gains made by redundancies?

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —With the greatest respect for Senator Tierney, the question is a nonsense because it is simply untrue. The Prime Minister said nothing of the sort. I would invite Senator Tierney to have a look at the 12 March statement. What the Prime Minister said in the House of Representatives I said here in the Senate, and we were quite explicit about it. What was achieved in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and announced by the Prime Minister in the 12 March statement was that an agreement in principle had been reached with the assistance of the Industrial Relations Commission-a body which, thank goodness, is still in operation and which the Opposition, of course, has pledged to abolish.

answer.para: What Senator Tierney says is an absolute nonsense. An agreement in principle has been reached. The parties then gave a commitment that a drafting committee would be set up, which has been set up. Conaust, in fact, on the front page of the Daily Commercial News, which is the major trade paper of the industry, announced that the target for the completion of that agreement would be May. That was confirmed by the union and that is still the case.

talk.start.para: —How is it going?

—It is going very well. The current situation-and the Minister for Industrial Relations has answered a question on a related issue, which is the national wage case-is that concurrently with that operation a major task is being undertaken in terms of award restructuring by the parties to the stevedoring reform process. That task has two aims. The first is to reduce the existing 20 awards in the industry to one award, and the second is to reduce the dozens of job classifications contained in that multitude of awards to around seven classifications, which has also been agreed to.

answer.para: I point out to the Opposition that the Inter-State Commission report, which in June 1989 the Opposition formally supported-and that is contained in the Hansard record of the House of Representatives-as containing recommendations that would provide real structural reform, and the Opposition was right about that, both anticipated and indeed recognised that there would be increases in pay for those people remaining in the industry, as well as incentives for those who were going to leave. Both parties agree to that.
In conclusion, the actual difference--

talk.start.para: —A 20 per cent increase, is it?
—Rubbish! What a load of nonsense.
—Tell us.

—I was about to do that before Senator Parer interrupted. I had actually used the words `the actual difference' when I was once again interrupted. To conclude, the actual difference between the parties is in fact tiny. It is a matter of 1 or 2 per cent. The appropriate opportunity to debate that in detail is at a later time and not in Question Time. If the honourable senator would like me to give him a detailed briefing on the log of claims made by both parties-not an unusual situation, I might add, in an industrial negotiation-he would find that the real difference between the parties is very small. There was a hearing of the Commission yesterday on this issue. A further hearing has been set down for Friday of this week, and I am confident that with the assistance of the Industrial Relations Commission the parties will resolve their differences in the normal manner.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It would be nice if we had an answer to the question that was asked. It was in three parts. Let me ask parts two and three again. What is the percentage wage increase being demanded by the unions? What we are after is very specific. To what extent would the wage increase demanded offset the gains made by redundancies?

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —It would be most inappropriate in the current circumstances, and totally counterproductive to getting a resolution-which of course is what the Opposition does not want achieved-to play the role of an industrial commissioner. As a matter of fact, I say for the second time on record that I am extremely happy with the way in which Commissioner Sweeney is very sensibly handling this matter. In terms of the original logs of claim, which are already being substantially changed in the course of this negotiation, the employers--
—What was it?
—Don't you know anything about ambit claims?

—Opposition senators have never heard of them. The Opposition thinks that this is a remarkable situation unique to the waterfront and that it does not happen anywhere else or in any other industry. In terms of wage claims, of course politicians are totally exempt from any interest in that matter. Every time a recommendation from the Remuneration Tribunal comes for increasing our salaries, we as a group rise up and say, `No, we do not want it; take it back'. The Opposition thinks that the only people who have an interest in increases in wages are waterside workers. The facts are that the matter is being handled where it should be handled-in the Industrial Commission, an organisation which the Opposition has pledged to abolish.

answer.para: What is currently happening with this negotiation does not concern me at all. However I would be profoundly concerned if the central wage fixing system were abolished, as the Opposition wants it abolished, so that strategically placed unions, such as the WWF, could play merry hell.

talk.start.para: —I raise two simple points of order, Mr President. The first is the one that you have ruled on frequently and which we have dealt with earlier this week in that Senator Collins is required to answer the question if he so chooses. The second point is that Senator Collins is debating the question quite clearly in what remains of his answer.
—Order! I was about to suggest to Senator Collins that this is a very long answer.
—Mr President, I plead guilty. I have to say that it is a reaction to having almost gone to sleep about three times in Question Time today.
—What is the answer?
—Give us some details.
—The answer is not helped by constant interjections. To conclude, the matter is being handled properly in the Industrial Commission and I am pleased that that is where it is being resolved.

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —During Question Time today I was asked two questions by Senator Hill and I now want to add to my answer. Senator Hill's questions were based on reports by Max Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald. These reports were false, as reference to the actual record of the Western Australian Royal Commission would show. I have sought a retraction from the Sydney Morning Herald and I will table a letter seeking retraction which I sent to the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday.

answer.para: It is no secret that trade unions in Western Australia and elsewhere in Australia have provided electoral funds to the Australian Labor Party (ALP). This is just a natural, unremarkable and legal part of political fundraising in a democracy such as ours. It is also no secret that, as a former secretary of the Trades and Labour Council (TLC) in Western Australia, I organised fundraising from unions for the ALP. I also organised advertisements in print media, radio and television, my name also being in advertisements and commercials all over the place as secretary of the TLC. Unions have always conducted these fundraising campaigns in Perth and elsewhere and will continue to do so. Union contributions to the ALP have always been open and above board, which is more than can be said about donations to the Liberal Party of Australia. I repeat that Max Walsh's reports were wrong and I have sought retraction of them from the Sydney Morning Herald. I am also seeking legal advice about those false reports.

There has never been any suggestion of improper conduct made toward me in my public life by employers, unions, governments and, until today, oppositions. I value my good reputation; it is a sound reputation and I consistently safeguard it. Senator Hill's questions to me are fundamentally offensive and scurrilous. I table the document.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I have been misrepresented. Just after midday on Friday, 12 April 1991, Fran Kelly recorded an interview with me for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) PM program. It lasted for about five minutes. While recognising that it may be edited, I expected it to go to air as an interview with me. It did not. The PM program put to air on Friday, 12 April, presented allegations about financial and other involvements by Australian Labor Party people in Western Australian in union elections, including a Transport Workers Union of Australia election in New South Wales. It ran for about seven minutes and included two small grabs, 49 words in total, from the five-minute interview I had done earlier that day.

speech.para: I did not hear the PM program and did not receive a transcript until yesterday afternoon. In the PM program Fran Kelly, who, I understand, is ex-3JJJ, asked a rhetorical question not of me but of her audience as follows:
Is money from Western Australia being used by unions in New South Wales?
She then asserted as follows:
There is some evidence to back up that link. Here is the former Finance Minister in the Hawke Government, Senator Peter Walsh.
Then came the first voice grab from my previous five-minute interview as follows:
Money from the Western Australian leaders' account was transferred to New South Wales for purposes of an intra State union election.

My clear recollection is that immediately preceding that grab were the words, `It has been reported that', which then, of course, becomes, `It has been reported that money has been transferred from the leaders' account' et cetera, et cetera. By omitting those words the ABC transformed what was a factual statement by me about what had been in last week's newspapers, into an assertion by me that money was transferred. It had previously been misdescribed as evidence. I can only say that had the witness been tendering evidence like that on oath in a court he would have been promptly placed in the slammer.

The interviewer, Kelly, was repeatedly told by me during the five-minute interview, and prior to the interview, that I had almost no knowledge of either the receipts or expenditure of the Western Australian branch of the Labor Party or the leaders' account, and that I had never been involved with that sort of Party administration. Nevertheless, she persisted in asking questions, it is now apparent, to get some words to misuse in support of conclusions pre-determined by the ABC.

Following an earlier call from my staff I rang the PM producer, Kerry Weal, just after 5 p.m. yesterday. She told me that the full tape, which was about five minutes, of the interview with me by Kelly had hit the floor on Friday evening-that is, it no longer existed. I asked her to treat my comments about the PM item-at least as they affected me-as a formal complaint.

Just before 5 p.m. I had spoken to Marian Wilkinson, the producer of the ABC's Four Corners program, in case Four Corners intended to use some of its first cousin's misrepresentations on its program last night, and explained what had been done by PM. Wilkinson told me that Four Corners would not be using it and added that her own reaction on hearing PM on Friday night was, `How would he'-that is, me-`know that?' There are sceptics even inside the ABC.

When putting together last Friday's PM program the ABC was clearly determined to weave some of my words, regardless of sense or context, into the fabric of its hypothesis. I do not believe its actions should be attributed to incompetence. The ABC wilfully misrepresented what I had said. There are several ABC precedents, but this was the most gross breach of journalistic ethics that I have personally encountered, with the possible exception of an item some 10 years ago by Ronald Andersen.

Whether the blame should be attributed to Kelly or Weal or both I do not know. I have been told-I believe reliably-that any journalist in the commercial electronic media who behaved similarly would be sacked. This, of course, will not happen in the ABC. At best, there will be an internal inquiry which will find the ABC innocent.

I give a bit of advice to all politicians, which I should have heeded. Do not appear on ABC current affairs programs unless they are broadcast live. Corrected though the ABC's misrepresentation now is, the mischief cannot be entirely undone. This gruesome misrepresentation by the ABC can, at any time in the future, be quoted from the seemingly authoritative source of PM on 12 April 1991.

petition.title: Tobacco Advertising
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Foreign Ownership
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Middle East
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

* The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle-East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle-East.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
* Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all of the people of the MiddleEast.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Port Hedland-Marble Bar Road
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
* The Port Hedland/Marble Bar road is in terrible condition;
* As far back as the early 1950s the people of Marble Bar were promised an all weather road;
* The poor state of the gravel road is deterring tourists from seeing the many attractions in the Marble Bar area and causing untold damage to the town's economy.
Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure that funds are made available for the essential upgrading of this important road.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

petition.title: Assets Test: Family Farm
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That family farming and small business assets are unsuitable for inclusion in the assets test for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm and the assets of other small businesses from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Telecom: 0055 Services
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Medications and Pensions
petition.para: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Retired Citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. Charging for prescriptions is causing hardship particularly to the people on more than one medication and also those with chronic illnesses.
2. Proposals to assess all retired peoples' savings above $2000 as receiving 10% interest is punitive, oppressive and discriminative.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled urge the Government to: stop the charge for Pensioners prescriptions and scrap the proposals to assess savings at 10% interest. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Education in ACT
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the Chubb Report on Higher Education for the A.C.T. which proposes that the Institute of Advanced Studies be separated from the Faculties of the Australian National University and the Faculties be amalgamated with the University of Canberra. We believe that the implementation of these proposals would mean the destruction of the Australian National University's national and international high standing and firmly established reputation as a centre of excellence in research and scholarship. The dismemberment of the ANU would severely effect the ability of both the Institute and the Faculties to attract, or even retain, high quality academic staff, funding and support. It would also adversely affect the recruitment of top students. The maintenance of the Australian National University, as it is now constituted-a national university with an international, national and local role-is of vital importance to the A.C.T. and Australia.
2. We call on the Senate to reject the recommendations of the Chubb report and to support the integrity of the ANU and the existing relationship between the Institute and the Faculties.

petition.title: Uranium: Mining and Export
petition.para: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium.
